<[silence:3400]>
Words as weapons. Debates as battlefields.
<[silence:2400]>
"Framing" means choosing words to shape how people see an issue—like picking a camera angle to change what’s in focus.<[silence:2400]

A tax can be called a "burden" (sounds heavy) or an "investment" (sounds smart).<[silence:1200]
Same policy, different reactions.<[silence:2400]

In 2003, the U.S. "invasion of Iraq" became a "liberation" in some speeches.<[silence:1200]
Same war, but "liberation" suggests freedom, not force.<[silence:2400]

Studies show: People oppose "estate taxes" but support "taxes on millionaire heirs"—even if it’s the same thing.<[silence:1200]
Words trigger emotions before logic.<[silence:2400]

Politicians use "hardworking families" (relatable) instead of "low-income households" (clinical).<[silence:1200]
Media calls protests "riots" or "uprisings"—one sounds chaotic, the other heroic.<[silence:2400]

Even science debates hinge on framing.<[silence:1200]
"Climate change" vs. "global warming"—one feels broader, one feels hotter.<[silence:1200]
Same data, different urgency.<[silence:2400]

Words don’t just describe debates.<[silence:1200]
They build the stage the debate happens on.<[silence:1200]

<[silence:1200]>
Cognitive biases.<[silence:1200]
Propaganda techniques.<[silence:1200]
The psychology of persuasion.
